theory_assignments.reasoning: Focuses on weakened purifying selection on late-acting deleterious germline mutations accumulating with age, causing aging.
Describes accumulation of late-acting deleterious germline variants due to weak selection at old age.
Emphasizes accumulation of late-acting deleterious mutations in germline affecting aging.
Discusses age-specific deleterious mutations accumulating in populations due to weak late-life selection.
Highlights age-dependent accumulation of deleterious germline mutations influenced by population size.
Focuses on accumulation of late-acting deleterious mutations in germline due to declining selection with age.
Describes age-specific accumulation of deleterious mutations with worsening effects contributing to aging.
Combines mutation accumulation and antagonistic pleiotropy focusing on late-acting deleterious germline mutations.
Muller's hypothesis on accumulation of recessive deleterious germline mutations increasing genetic load.
Hamilton's force of selection theory explaining senescence via declining selection on late-acting germline mutations.
Classic evolutionary theories including mutation accumulation of germline mutations causing aging.
Evolutionary genetic theory emphasizing genetic basis of aging shaped by natural selection on germline variants.
Differential survival and selective culling affecting gene pool composition and aging-related disease susceptibility.
Genetic polymorphisms modulating cancer susceptibility and longevity via germline variants.
Condition-dependent mortality shaping lifespan evolution via selective disappearance affecting gene pool.
Classical theory linking sex-specific life history and resource allocation trade-offs to aging patterns.
Classical evolutionary theories positing inevitability of senescence due to evolutionary forces on germline.
Senescence as decline in residual reproductive value linked to evolutionary decline in fitness with age.
Focuses on somatic mutation accumulation rate as determinant of lifespan and aging.
Somatic mutation accumulation causing cellular dysfunction and organismal aging.
Mutation accumulation in yeast somatic cells linked to lifespan shortening.
Somatic mutation accumulation in long-lived trees with limits on mutation burden.
Somatic mutations in neurons causing brain aging and neurodegeneration.
Somatic CAG repeat instability causing neurodegenerative disease aging.
Oxidative nucleotide pool sanitization reducing somatic mutation accumulation and aging.
